awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO: Electrocortical Processes in Real World Locomotion
awd_abstract_narration:
Technology for mobile brain imaging with electroencephalography (EEG) has advanced in recent years, but it is still difficult to capture electrical brain dynamics while people move in the real world. The body movement of walking and running creates considerable motion and muscle artifacts, making it difficult to determine what is true brain activity. This project proposes to advance electrode technology and signal processing of EEG to enable measurement of brain electrical activity outside the laboratory in the real world, including playing tennis, a complex, active, goal-directed motor task. The project will use novel methods to measure brain electrical activity as people walk on a university campus. Some subjects will be physically intact; some will have lower limb amputations. The technological and scientific advancements from these studies will permit future use of mobile EEG for clinical diagnosis and rehabilitation, as well as development of new mobile brain computer interfaces.

To understand how the human brain works in the real world, it is necessary to study human brain dynamics in real-world environments and tasks. Stationary functional brain imaging techniques like magnetic resonance imaging and magnetoencephalography are inherently limited in studying brain function of people moving through the real world. Creating and validating new mobile brain imaging methods with both good temporal and spatial resolution are necessary to advance neuroscience and facilitate non-invasive brain computer interfaces for real-world use. This project will combine high-density EEG with independent component analysis and source localization to identify brain areas involved in the control and active perception of moving in real-world urban and natural environments and in playing tennis. Motion and muscle artifacts complicate interpretation of EEG data during active whole body movement. New hardware and software solutions are necessary to increase the quality of EEG as a mobile brain imaging tool during locomotion. This project will advance novel dual-layer EEG electrodes that can cancel motion artifacts and improve the fidelity of electrocortical measures. The project combines cognitive neuroscience, signal processing, sensor technology, biomechanics, and motor control to make recordings of human brain dynamics that have never been made before. The advances and validation of neurotechnology will provide neuroscientists with new capabilities to transform the study of human brain function in the real world. This research will advance technology for mobile brain imaging and provide new insight into the cortical control of human movement in health and disability.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on measruing human brain activity in real world tasks. We used high-density electroencephalography with novel dual-electrodes to remove motion artifact from participants playing table tennis. We showed that brain activity can be reliably recorded during a real world human movement task that requires visual tracking, discrete body movements, and a clear goal related tasks. There are clear patterns of increased desynchronization and synchronization of neural signals that can be tapped into for brain computer interfaces or ergonomics purposes. In addition, we showed that brain activity playing against a human opponent is different than playing against a robot opponent. There is a greater attention and awareness to robot actions than human actions, likely because it is easier to read the intent of the human opponent from body language. In addition to the published studies on the data, we demonstrated that advanced signal processing algorithms developed in our laboratory can clean the EEG data in ways above and beyond other existing algorithms. Another branch of the research compared motor behavior and brain activity for playing real table tennis with a video game analog of table tennis (i.e. Pong). Results show differences in brain activity that reflect the simplified brain processes for Pong compared to table tennis. We also collected data on human walking on a treadmill in a laboratory and also walking in a nature setting outdoors. In both cases, they completed a visual search task to elicit a clear brain response for succes of the task. Results show there were unique confounders outdoors in the real world on brain activity that were difficult to predict (e.g. interaction with other humans in the park led to increased stress comprared to completing the task in a lab on a treadmill, there were added electromagnetic interference signals from power lines outdoors that were not expected, etc.). In addition to papers analyzing the results, we also uploaded data from table tennis and walking experiments on open access internet databases for others to analyze as secondary research projects. These are available on OpenNeuro and IEEE DataPort. Lastly, we examined how humans with lower limb amputations walk in the real world and in a laboratorywith a bionic, myoelectrically controlled lower limb prosthesis copmpared to their prescribed prosthesis. Results show that amputees tend to activate the bionic prostheses to produce mechanics similar to their prescribed prostheses, likely because they are so used to walking with a given gait pattern it is hard to walk differently. The motor memory of their gait pattern wins over the possiblity of producing much higher ankle mechanical power. The technological achievements made with the study advance mobile brain imaging research and bionic lower limb prosthetic research.
